subject: Re: [junit] setUp versus constructors

messageBody:
I see that I removed the jdt part of the stacktrac in the first example and
not the second. In all fairness I fixed that below:

On 7/19/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> The reason I started to use setUp instead of a constructor can be
> illustrated by two examples, they both do the same but one of them throws an
> exception from the constructor and the other throws an exception from the
> setup method. I think that the exception thrown from the setup method is
> slightly easier to read and looks more like you would expect a failure to
> look like from withing a test. It is a subtle difference but it made me pick
> setUp over constructors.
>
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
>
> public class TestSetup extends TestCase {
> public void setUp () {
> assertTrue(false);
> }
> public void testSomething() throws Exception {
>
> }
> }
>
>
> fails with this message:
>
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:20)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue (Assert.java:27)
> at com.agical.rmock.core.TestSetup.setUp(TestSetup.java:7)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:125)
> at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:118)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest (TestSuite.java:208)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:203)
>
> while this example:
>
> package com.agical.rmock.core;
>
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
>
> public class TestConstructor extends TestCase {
> public TestConstructor () {
> assertTrue(false);
> }
>
> public void testSomething() throws Exception {
>
> }
> }
>
> fails with the slightly harder to read (IMO <init> is a bit more magical
> and can confuse novice users, in addition you have a some extra stacktrace,
> something that is hidden in eclipse but not in ant (I think)) :
>
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Exception in constructor:
> testSomething (junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue (Assert.java:20)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:27)
> at com.agical.rmock.core.TestConstructor.<init>(TestConstructor.java
> :7)
> at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Native Method)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.createTest(TestSuite.java:131)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.addTestMethod(TestSuite.java:114)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.<init>(TestSuite.java:75)
> )
> at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite$1.runTest(TestSuite.java:263)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:127)
> at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.run (TestCase.java:118)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:208)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:203)
>
>
>
>
>
